  • Description: 1. X-2024010703 THE LEAKING CLASS 8 HAZMAT WAS RESPONDED TO BY RESPONDER IN DOOR 216 AND RETURNED TO THE PSC FOR PROCESSING. ALL MERCHANDISE WAS DAMAGED BY THE SPILL AND PROCESSED THROUGH THE DMP AS A LIQUID. 2. X-2024010704 THE PACKAGE SERVICE CENTER RECIEVED A CALL FOR A LEAKING HAZMAT PACKAGE. A DESIGNATED RESPONDER WAS THEN DISPATCHED TO THE LOCATION OF THE LEAKING HAZMAT PACKAGE. THE DR THEN CONTAINERIZED THE LEAKING PACKAGE AND TRANSPORTED IT BACK TO THE PSC FOR FURTHER PROCESSING. ONCE AT THE PSC THE DR FOLLOWED THE DAMAGED MATERIALS PROCESS TO DISPOSE OF THE LEAKING HAZMAT.

item.title: Report E-2024010469
item.description:
Report E-2024010469

Identified by scraper @ 2024-01-30T15:10:41+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-01-22
  • City: WILMINGTON
  • State: OH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R&L CARRIERS SHARED SERVICES, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On January 22, 2024, one (1) 500-pound cylinder of UN1009 was hissing when moved and covered in ice. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Thin Line Environmental (TLE) to inspect the cylinder and remediate the site. TLE personnel inspected the cylinder for any punctures or damage. No damage was found. Crews observed the cylinder was off gassing, creating a reaction. TLE personnel utilized hand tools, and absorbent pads, to remove ice from the frozen cylinder. Crews then moved the cylinder to the OS&D heat room, so the cylinder could gently warm up, and continue to release all of its contents. TLE personnel verified the cylinder released all of its contents and finished off gassing. Crews estimated 186 pounds of gas released. TLE personnel recommended the cylinder warm up a few hours before sending it for continued processing and shipping. All Ansul Halon 1301 (UN1009) impacted material was collected and containerized in one (1) 5-gallon pail and R+L personnel took possession of the waste to be added to the facility waste stream.

item.title: Report E-2024010458
item.description:
Report E-2024010458

Identified by scraper @ 2024-01-30T15:10:41+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-01-18
  • City: ROCK RIVER
  • State: WY
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On January 18, 2024, at 0200 EST, an XPO Logistics tractor trailer hauling double trailers (truck # 05328716, trailer #s 03171129, 03171874) was involved in a rollover accident due to inclement weather conditions. Immediately after the accident occurred, the roads to the site were closed due to the weather and the unit was left onsite. No drains or waterways were reported to be impacted by the release. On January 18, 2024, at 0256 EST, XPO Logistics contacted Emergency Response and Training Solutions (ERTS) to manage and oversee the above referenced incident. ERTS secured Haz-Mat Response Inc. (HMRI) to perform emergency response and remediation. On January 18, 2024, HMRI responded to the site at 1140 ET to obtain an assessment of the site. At the time, there was no visual release of material from the unit, but it was also in 5-6” of snow. Once HMRI left site, the wrecker unit showed up at approximately 1300 ET to haul the unit offsite. Initially they did not report seeing a release of material when the unit was up righted. On January 19th, HMRI mobilized to the wrecker yard to find the batteries had released approximately 50-100 gallons of battery acid to the trailer floor, walls, ceiling, and soil along the passenger side of the unit in the wrecker yard. An estimated 5-gallons of acid impacted a 26’ x 1’ area of the soil in the dirt lot. Soda ash and floor dry were deployed to the impacted trailer floor to neutralize the acid. The wrecker crew then advise to HMRI there was a loss of acid to the incident site in the soil median where the unit came to a rest. HMRI secured the unit at the wrecker’s yard and mobilized to the accident site where they confirmed an approximate 2-gallon release to a 5’ x 15’ area of the median ditch. The area was hand excavated and all impacted soil placed into a drum which was removed from site. At this point, the 7-gallons of material confirmed to impact soil/dirt was reported to the WY DEQ. On January 22, 2024, at 1100 ET, HMRI returned to the wrecker yard to complete trailer remediation. Each battery was wiped down and inspected. All 70 salvageable batteries were secured on the unit on 4 pallets to be hauled back to XPO with the unit. The trailer floor was neutralized with soda ash and floor dry, and the soil was hand excavated. A total of 213 damaged batteries were containerized into (9) 95-gallon poly drums and will attempt to be recycled. All impacted debris including the impacted floor dry, soda ash, soil, dirt, poly sheeting, cardboard, and PPE were collected and containerized into (2) 55-gallon poly and (3) 95-gallon poly drums for disposal. All waste is currently located at HMRI’s shop located in Windsor, CO pending profiling, disposal, and recycling. Please see attached photos (Appendix 2).

Identified by scraper @ 2024-01-30T15:10:41+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-01-16
  • City: SULPHUR
  • State: KY
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: CLEAN HARBORS ENVIRONMENTAL SERVICES, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: The driver was traveling on I-71WB in KY when a passer by flagged him down. He then pulled off at the Sulfur Ky exit and inspected his load he noticed a frozen material at the back door of the trailer. The driver then grabbed some absorbent to put down at the back of the trailer to prevent material from getting on the ground. The driver then called our emergency line at 1351ET to report the incident. The team was dispatched and arrived at 1745ET to start the clean up. The team dawned the proper PPE and proceeded to clean up the frozen material at the back of the trailer. There was aprxemetly 1-2oz that made it to the ground everything else was contained to the trailer and absorbent wags. Once that was cleaned they opened the trailer and found material frozen on the floor and proceeded to clean it up. They then gained access to the drum that was about half way in the trailer and found that the bottom of the drum has approximately 1in crack at the bottom. The team put the damaged container into a salvage drum along with absorbents used to clean up the material. The team was able to finish the clean up around 0100ET.

  • City: LOUISVILLE
  • State: KY
  • Report Type: Undeclared Shipment with no Release

  • Hazmat Injuries: 0

  • Description: AT THE UPS WORLDPORT FACILITY IN LOUISVILLE, KY AN AIR PACKAGE WET FROM RAINWATER WAS BEING REWRAPPED WHEN AN INNER BOX WAS FOUND WITH A UN3481 LITHIUM BATTERY MARK. UPON FURTHER INSPECTION OF THE INNER CONTENTS DISCOVERED THREE LITHIUM ION BATTERIES CONTAINED IN EQUIPMENT. THERE IS ONE HP OFFICE JET 200 MOBILE PRINTER WITH A UN3481 LABEL ON THE CONSUMER PACKAGING. THERE IS A LITHIUM-ION BATTERY PACK ATTACHED TO THE PRINTER, MODEL NUMBER CZ993-60017. THERE IS ANOTHER BOX INSIDE THE PACKAGE THAT CONTAINS ONE PANASONIC TOUGHBOOK WITH TWO ATTACHED LITHIUM-ION BATTERY PACKS, MODEL NUMBER FZ-VSU1HU. THERE ARE ALSO ADDITIONAL NON-DANGEROUS GOODS ITEMS INSIDE THE PACKAGE. THERE ARE NO DANGEROUS GOODS MARKS OR LABELS ON THE OUTER BOX TO INDICATE LITHIUM ION BATTERIES CONTAINED IN EQUIPMENT PRODUCTS WERE BEING SHIPPED IN THE AIR NETWORK. PRIOR TO DISCOVERY THE PACKAGE WAS FLOWN ON UPS AIRCRAFT FROM ATL TO SDF.

THERE ARE NO DANGEROUS GOODS MARKS OR LABELS ON THE OUTER BOX TO INDICATE DRY ICE WAS BEING SHIPPED AIR SERVICE. OUTER BOX HAS A GREEN STICKER APPLIED "REFRIGERATE CONTROLS UPON ARRIVAL". THE BOX IS A ULINE INSULATED SHIPPER BOX PREPRINTED RUSH AND PERISHABLE WITH ORIENTATION UP ARROWS. A PACKING LIST IS IN A POUCH ON THE SIDE OF THE BOX AND DOES INDICATE THE CONTENTS HIV RAPID CONTROL PACK AND "SHIP WITH DRY ICE AND STORE AT 2-8 C UPON ARRIVAL". DUE TO THE FOLDING PATTERN THE DRY ICE INFORMATION SHOWING UNDER THE STORAGE COLUMN ON THE PACKING LIST WAS NOT VISIBLE. THE PACKAGE WAS SCANNED INTO AN AIR CONTAINER FOR FLIGHT BUT WAS NOT FLOWN.

item.title: Report E-2024010447
item.description:
Report E-2024010447

Identified by scraper @ 2024-01-29T15:11:25+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-01-24
  • City: COLUMBUS
  • State: OH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal XCO experienced a UN3264 Kroff KR-B3020 release from a 330-gallon poly tote. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 100-gallons of product released to an 8’ x 20’ area of the trailer floor due to a forklift puncture. The material was transferred from the damaged tote into a new one. Sodium bicarb and absorbents were then deployed and worked into the impacted area to clean and neutralize the release. The impacted absorbents and cleanup debris were then collected and containerized into a 55-gallon poly drum. The damaged tote was cut up and containerized into an 85-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: A FULLY LABELED HAZMAT PACKAGE THAT APPEARED TO BE LEAKING FROM THE CORNER OF THE BOX WAS DISCOVERED BY THE HVD PICKOFF ON THE PD 4. THE PICKOFF STOPPED THE BELT, SECURED IT, LOCKED IT, TESTED IT, THEN LEFT THE AREA AND NOTIFIED THE SUPERVISOR. WITHIN 5 MINUTES A DMP RESPONDER ARRIVED DONNING THE CORRECT PPE. USING THE DECISION TREE AND APPROPRIATE RESPONSE SHEET IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE PACKAGE COULD BE SAFELY TRANSPORTED BACK TO THE DMP. UPON FURTHER INSPECTION IT WAS REVEALED THAT THE LID ON ONE OF THE PLASTIC 2.5 LITER INNER CONTAINERS WAS LOOSE BY 1/4 TURN AND 2 OUNCES OF LIQUID HAD LEAKED OUT ONTO THE OUTER CARTON. THE OUTER CARTON WAS A DOUBLE WALLED FIPERBOARD BOX AND THERE WAS NO INNER PACKAGING.

  • City: EARTH CITY

  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: FULLY LABELED HAZ-MAT SHIPMENT WAS VISUALLY DISCOVERED WET IN APPEARANCE BY A SORTER IN PRIMARY SORT AISLE-3. WITHOUT TOUCHING THE PKG HE EVACUATED THE AREA AND NOTIFIED HIS IMMEDIATE SUPERVISOR. DMP WAS CONTACTED AND WITHIN 2 MINUTES A DESIGNATED RESPONDER ARRIVED, DONNING THE PROPER PPE AND WITH A FULLY STOCKED SPILL CART. AFTER FOLLOWING THE DECISION TREE APPROPRIATE RESPONSE SHEET THE DAMAGE WAS CONTAINED (NO SPILLAGE OUTSIDE OF CARTON), THEN TRANSPORTED TO THE DMP PROCESSING AREA. CLOSER INSPECTION REVEALED THAT THE CAP ON 1 OF 1 POLY 1-GALLON JUGS WAS LOOSE BY A FULL ROTATION, CAUSING APPROX. 6 OUNCES OF THE LIQUID TO SPILL THROUGH THE BREACH AND INTO THE CARTON. THERE WAS NO INTERNAL PACKING MATERIAL AND THE OUTER CARTON WAS A SINGLEWALL FIBERBOARD BOX, RATED AT A 44 LBS/IN EDGE CRUSH TEST (ECT).

item.title: Report E-2024010441
item.description:
Report E-2024010441

Identified by scraper @ 2024-01-26T15:11:09+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-01-17
  • City: JAMAICA
  • State: NY
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: JET BLUE AIRWAYS
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: While boarding flight 149 JFK to GND. The FO and CA were waiting for refueling to be completed before doing the before start checked to the line. The F3, came in the cockpit and said there was a “medical issue” he then corrected and said ”safety issue in the jetway”. The CA was walking into the galley was told it was a bag fire in the jetway. When he stepped into the jetway, he observed a wet bag, 2 empty water bottles, and fire extinguisher, next to an open bag. It had a blue battery disconnected from the bag. The F1 was watching over it with fire gloves. The CA then asked all in the jetway (starting to get crowded) if fire rescue was notified and was told ops knows about it. He immediately went into the cockpit and called ground operations to let them know they were had a bag fire in the jetway that appeared to be out. He also mentioned that he believed ops had informed Port authority but would confirm. He called OPS on the radio and they knew. He asked them to call the Port Authority to have the bag looked at. They said they would. On his way back to the jetway he noticed all the customers were in their seats he checked on the bag. No fire and then made a PA to let the customers know all was safe and what had happened. After things settled down it became clear to me what an amazing job the Flight attendants did. The F1 said she observed the customer walking down the jetway rolling a smoking bag. She stoped the customer prevented the bag from getting on the aircraft and called for safety team on the PA. She and the team went into action and by the time I got to the jetway, they had the fire out the battery cooled with water and the customers in their seats. Obviously the aircraft passageway was initially clogged with bags customers etc. that was cleared and the F3 got to the cockpit to let us know about the issue. I can’t say enough about how well the flight attendants did. The suitcase was found to contain a medical refrigerator, manufactured by North Sciences. The battery connected to the refrigerator was a 120 wH, Lithium Ion Battery. It's only markings were as follows: Stirling Engine Li-ion Battery Model: JCB2405A Rated: 24V-5000mAh-120Wh Date: 2021-7 All other markings were in foreign language. The bag also contained a Power Supply Unit, manufacturer unknown. It had a Lithium Ion battery rated at 257.52 Wh. It did not go into thermal runaway and did not contribute to the event. Both items were confiscated and placed on internal reports DGR53-24 (battery) and DGR64-24 (Power Supply).

  • Description: On January 16, 2024, one (1) 275-gallon tote of UN3266 was failing near the valve and leaked approximately less than one (<1) gallon of product to the loading dock floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from EnviroServe (ES) to remediate the impacted site. ES personnel utilized hand tools and absorbents to remediate the UN3266-impacted loading dock to the extent practicable. Crews transferred the remaining product from the damaged tote to a new one. The damaged tote and all impacted debris were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum and one (1) 35-gallon drum for transport and disposal.

  • Description: On January 16, 2024, two (2) 5-gallon pails of gun wash (UN1993) were punctured by a forklift and released approximately ten (10) gallons of products to the trailer interior and adjacent boxes of masking paper. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from First Call Environmental (FCE) to remediate the impacted site. FCE personnel deployed granular absorbents to the gun wash fluid-impacted trailer interior and swept them in with hand tools. All spent absorbents were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum, the damaged containers were containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum and the impacted masking paper was placed into one (1) additional 55-gallon drum for terminal disposal.

item.title: Report E-2024010157
item.description:
Report E-2024010157

Identified by scraper @ 2024-01-25T15:11:44+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-01-04
  • City: SELKIRK
  • State: NY
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: CSX CORPORATION
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On 01/04/2024, at 1336 hours, personnel at the CSX yard in Selkirk, New York, reported product leaking from inside the valve box of car LTCX 1902, a tank car loaded with Argon, refrigerated liquid. The car was isolated and the shipper, Linde Inc., was notified via CHEMTREC (Report 2024-0104-00121). David Scoons, a CSX Senior Manager of Hazardous Materials, responded to the incident and determined the cause of the release was a loose coupler fitting on a gauge panel feed line. Response personnel tightened the loose coupler fitting and stopped the release. The shipper’s representative, Timothy Lavallee (716-225-0242), was notified of the condition found and the corrective actions taken.

  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal LJS experienced a UN3286 EC1417A release from a 350-gallon metal tote. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 0.5-gallons of product released to a 1’ x 1’ area of the trailer floor as well as the tote body. The lid to the tote was not secure causing a release. The tote and impacted trailer floor were wiped down and cleaned with simple green. All impacted pads and PPE were then placed into a 55-gallon poly drum. The crew removed and cleaned the gasket which was then reseated, they then tightened the bolts and conducted a slosh test to ensure there would be no further release. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Description: On January 16, 2024, one (1) 225-gallon tote of UN2922 was crushed in transit and released approximately two (2) gallons of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from HazChem Environmental (HCE) to remediate the impacted site. HCE personnel deployed granular absorbents to the UN2922-impacted trailer and swept them in with hand tools. All spent absorbents were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum to be staged onsite for future disposal. HCE personnel transferred the product from the 255-gallon tote into one (1) 330-gallon tote for further shipment.

item.description:
Report E-2024010386

Identified by scraper @ 2024-01-24T15:11:38+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-01-17
  • City: CHEROKEE
  • State: AL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: AIRGAS USA, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Driver encountered deteriorating roadway conditions on his way to make delivery to the customer. At some point driver claims that a 3rd party driver veered into his lane causing him to take minor evasive action. This lead to loss of control when he contacted an icy road surface. The tanktruck rolled into the median where it came to rest. Ther was a rupture of a vapor valve as well as the diesel fuel tank. Luckily due to the cold weather only minor amounts of ammonia were lost through the vapor break. The police and local fire department were called to the scene to set up roadblocks and control the area. The Huntsville, AL Hazmat team eventually made it to the site to assess the situation. It was deemed feasible to set the truck upright and tow away to a remote location for product offload and depressurization. Fugitive vapors were controlled by water application by the FD. A fuel cleanup team has been assigned to remove soil and diesel fuel as well.

  • Description: On January 19, 2024, at 2053 ET, XPO notified ERTS of a cargo release at terminal LEP. It was reported that approximately 1-gallon of El Pinol 85 (Pine Oil 60%) UN1272 was released from 55-gallon metal drum due to pinhole puncture. The release impacted the dock and trailer floor. ERTS reviewed the SDS with the caller and they felt comfortable that terminal personnel was capable of cleaning the release with PPE available on-site. The terminal did not have a drum large enough to overpack the damaged drum that was leaking. ERTS dispatched contractors to drop off an 85-gallon metal drum for terminal personnel. Once arrived, terminal personnel placed the damaged drum and all impacted absorbents into the drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.title: Report E-2024010383
item.description:
Report E-2024010383

Identified by scraper @ 2024-01-24T15:11:38+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-12-19
  • City: NEWBURGH
  • State: NY
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: A DUIE PYLE INC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On December 19, 2023, at 0711 ET, Emergency Response and Training Solutions (ERTS) was contacted by A Duie Pile personnel in Newburgh, NY regarding the release of an unknown amount of various products due to a multiple vehicle accident (The speed of the vehicle is unknown). Contractors were dispatched to the site to perform all onsite clean-up activities. Upon arrival, contractors confirmed the release of multiple materials which included KEM AQUA® 400 Waterborne Enamel (UN1263, 3, III), Polane Plus Enamel (Part A) (UN1263, 3, III), and a Flammable Liquid, Corrosive, n.o.s. (UN1263, 3, II). Contractors were unable to assess approximately how much of each were released due to the materials mixing with each other. Contractors were able to clean the release with absorbents and the proper PPE. All waste generated was containerized in (7) 55-gallon poly drum, and (7) 55-gallon metal drum which was then taken offsite by contractors for proper disposal.

(UN2922, 8, II) from (1) 55-gallon poly drums. Contractors were dispatched and upon arrival, contractors confirmed the material and the amount of the release. Contractors were able to to clean the release with absorbents and the proper PPE, and the leaking drum's top was tighten and secured to be forwarded on to the original consignee. All waste generated was containerized in (1) 55-gallon poly drum which was then taken offsite by contractors for proper disposal.

  • City: ROCK ISLAND
  • State: IL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS FREIGHT, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Due to a forklift accident, a 55-gallon poly drum containing ChemTreat BL1544 was punctured and released approximately 10-gallons of product onto the concrete, dock floor and asphalt beneath the trailer. A contractor overpacked the damaged drum and neutralized the spilled product with Kolorsafe Base Neutralizer. The spill debris was placed into (2) 55DF's for waste disposal along with the overpack drum. No storm-drains, waterways, or soil were impacted by the release.
